Dry reforming methane (DRM) is a method that produces hydrogen, which is highly promotional and environmentally relevant. In addition to providing a route to cleaner energy production via hydrogen fuel, it offers a double environmental advantage by utilizing two powerful greenhouse gases at the same time: CO₂ and CH₄. The DRM at 700 °C was tested using a series of 5 % Ni-based catalysts promoted with 1 % Rh, La, Au, and Sm and supported on alumina. The catalysts were prepared via the impregnation method. The textural qualities, reducibility, structural features, basicity, carbon deposition, morphology, and surface chemical states were examined using N₂ physisorption, H₂-TPR, XRD, CO₂-TPD, Raman spectroscopy, TEM, and XPS. Rh addition significantly increased the catalytic activity, resulting in the highest H₂ and CO yields (approximately 60 % and 70 %, respectively) and an H₂/CO ratio of 0.85. However, when compared to the unpromoted 5Ni/Al₂O₃ catalyst, the addition of La, Au, and Sm resulted in a decline in catalytic performance, highlighting the selectivity of promoter effectiveness. According to characterization investigations, La, Au, and Sm promotion increased coke deposition, which was validated by Raman spectroscopy, while Rh promotion promoted higher reducibility and improved the dispersion of Ni nanoparticles. TEM investigation of the spent 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3 catalyst revealed that carbon nanotubes and nanofibers encapsulated the active sites. XPS analysis revealed the presence of NiAl₂O4 species in both fresh 5Ni/Al2O3 and 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3 catalysts. The Rh-promoted catalyst showed a modest shift towards higher binding energies, indicating improved metal-support interactions. Using response surface methods, this study examines how temperature, space velocity (SV), and the ratio of CH₄ to CO₂ affect the CO and H₂ yields and their ratios. The findings indicate that the most important component is temperature, which significantly increases the CO and H₂ output. These yields are also improved by lowering SV and the CH₄/CO₂ ratio. As a result, the H₂/CO ratio increased with higher temperature and lower SV, but it also increased with both temperature and CH₄/CO₂. In DRM, the ideal conditions for the 1 % Rh-promoted Ni catalyst were determined through numerical optimization, yielding over 95 % H2 yield. The experimental findings closely matched the theoretical expectations. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hydrogen Methane dry reforming Promoted catalysts Al2O3 Response Surface Methodology Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Dry reforming of methane (DRM) represents a significant catalytic process for the conversion of two principal greenhouse gases, CH₄ and CO₂, into synthesis gas (H₂/CO mixture) (Eq. (1)). This transformation pathway simultaneously addresses environmental concerns associated with atmospheric greenhouse gas accumulation, while generating valuable chemical feedstock applicable across multiple industrial sectors [1–3]. The stoichiometric composition of the synthesis gas produced via this process yielded a H₂/CO ratio of 1. This specific ratio is optimal for downstream applications, including the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis of liquid hydrocarbons [4]. Despite its promising environmental and economic implications, large-scale industrial adoption of DMR is constrained by significant technical barriers, predominantly associated with rapid catalyst deactivation mechanisms [5]. These mechanisms include carbonaceous deposit accumulation (coking) and thermal sintering of active metal particles at elevated operational temperatures, which are essential for endothermic reaction kinetics (Eqs. (2)–4). Furthermore, the considerable thermodynamic stability of methane, characterized by CH bond dissociation energies of approximately 440 kJ/mol, necessitates the development of catalytic materials with exceptional activities to achieve commercially viable conversion efficiencies and reaction rates under practical process conditions [6]. The strongly endothermic nature of DRM requires high operating temperatures (usually between 650 and 1000 °C) to obtain the best conversion rates [7]. Thermodynamic analysis indicates a negative correlation between the Gibbs free energy of the DRM reaction and temperature, below 640 °C [8–11]. The principal reactions governing the DRM process as well as side reactions during DRM are as follows: (1) C H 4 + C O 2 ↔ 2 CO + 2 H 2 ( Δ H 298 K = + 247.3 kJ / mol ) (2) 2 CO ↔ C O 2 + C ( Δ H 298 K = − 171.0 kJ / mol ) ( Boudouard reaction ) (3) C H 4 ↔ 2 H 2 + C ( Δ H 298 K = + 75 kJ / mol ) ( Methane cracking ) (4) C O 2 + H 2 ↔ CO + H 2 O ( Δ H 298 K = + 41.0 kJ / mol ) ( Reverse water − gas shift ) The most frequently employed noble-free metal catalysts for DRM are Ni-based catalysts dispersed on alumina (Al2O₃) substrates, because of their economic feasibility and performance characteristics [12,13]. The scientific literature consistently attributes superior performance and reduced carbon deposition to noble metal catalysts in the DRM process; however, their limited availability and prohibitive cost preclude their application in industrial-scale operations [14]. The Ni loading percentage exerts a significant influence on the catalyst efficacy in DRM reactions [15]. A comprehensive investigation by Pirshahid et al. [16] demonstrated a positive correlation between catalytic performance and nickel loading in the range of 5–15 wt. % on Ni/Al₂O₃-SiO₂ catalysts, with subsequent performance deterioration observed at 20 wt. % Ni content. This relationship suggests the existence of an optimal metal loading threshold beyond which detrimental effects predominate [17]. Selvarajah et al.; [3] reported the synthesis of 10 % Ni/Al₂O₃ catalyst via wet impregnation. Characterization studies revealed the concurrent formation of NiO and NiAl₂O₄ phases on the catalyst surface during calcination. The catalyst exhibited a notable specific surface area of 106.36 m² g⁻¹ with enhanced metal dispersion. Experimental observations indicated that the H₂/CO ratio consistently remained below unity, whereas the H₂ yield increased proportionally with the CO₂ partial pressure, achieving a maximum yield of approximately 70 %. Microscopic analysis confirmed the heterogeneous nature of the carbon deposits, which were characterized by the simultaneous presence of carbon nanofibers and graphitic carbon structures. In conjunction with active phase optimization, support material selection is a critical determinant of catalytic behavior and carbon deposition resistance. Aluminum oxide (Al₂O₃) has been extensively utilized as a support matrix for Ni-based DRM catalysts due to its advantageous physicochemical properties, including specific surface area, cost-effectiveness, chemical stability, and thermal resilience [1,3,18]. Yan et al.; [19] synthesized Al₂O₃-supported Ni catalysts exhibiting enhanced resistance to carbonaceous deposition during DRM, attributed to the formation of well-dispersed, nano-sized Ni particles stabilized by strong metal-support interactions at the Ni-Al₂O₃ interface. Similarly, Li et al.; [20] reported that Ni catalysts supported on wire-morphology Al₂O₃ demonstrated both superior catalytic activity and carbon resistance, properties ascribed to robust metal-support interactions, and optimal dispersion of small-diameter Ni nanoparticles across the support surface. From a mechanistic perspective, Yang et al.; [18] elucidated that the inherent Lewis acidity of γ-Al₂O₃ promotes methane decomposition pathways, thereby enhancing initial DRM activity. Paradoxically, this same characteristic contributes to catalyst deactivation, as Al₂O₃-supported Ni catalysts remain susceptible to significant carbon accumulation resulting from accelerated CH₄ decomposition kinetics in the absence of sufficient carbon gasification pathways. To enhance its anti-coking ability, modification of Ni-based catalysts through the incorporation of noble metals at low concentrations results in economically feasible catalytic systems that exhibit enhanced catalytic properties and diminished susceptibility to carbon formation [21,22]. For instance, the noble metal rhodium enhances catalytic efficacy through multiple mechanisms: improving Ni dispersion, inhibiting sintering processes, and CH₄ activation on the catalyst surface [23–25]. This performance enhancement is ascribed to the synergistic interaction between Rh and Ni species, which promotes active site formation and substantially improves the catalyst stability under reaction conditions [9]. In related work, a study by Ocsachoque et al.; [11] demonstrated that Rh and Ce (3 %) incorporation into Ni/α-Al₂O₃ catalyst significantly enhanced the DRM activity and stability compared to the unmodified catalyst. The superior catalytic performance was attributed to synergistic interactions between the Rh and Ce phases, which optimized the Rh dispersion and increased the active surface area. Li et al.; [24] conducted a comparative study using incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) and atomic layer deposition (ALD) techniques for synthesizing Rh/γ-Al₂O₃ catalysts. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis revealed that the ALD-synthesized catalysts exhibited reduced particle dimensions and narrower size distributions compared to their IWI counterparts. The ALD-derived catalyst demonstrated superior conversion and selectivity in the DRM reactions. Stability assessments indicated comparable performance between the ALD and IWI catalysts at 500 °C, while the ALD catalysts exhibited enhanced stability at elevated temperatures (800 °C). Cheng et al.; [23] investigated the influence of alumina crystal phases (γ- and α -) on hydrothermal stability and properties of Rh species in Rh/Al₂O₃ catalysts. Their experimental evidence suggested that both γ-Al₂O₃ and α-Al₂O₃ effectively reduced the occluded Rh content while simultaneously enhancing Rh stability during hydrothermal aging. Zhang et al.; [26] synthesized mesoporous NiAl₂O₄/γ-Al₂O₃ and NiAl₂O₄/MOx (M = La, Ce, Ca, Mg)-γ-Al₂O₃ systems and evaluated their catalytic performance on DRM. Comprehensive characterization confirmed the successful formation of NiAl₂O ₃ spinel structures after calcination at 800 °C, which significantly enhanced the nickel dispersion and strengthened the metal-support interactions. Among the various metal oxide promoters investigated, La-modified Ni/γ-Al₂O₃ exhibited superior catalytic activity and stability, likely due to the synergistic effect between the La₂O₃ promoter and nickel active sites, optimizing both the electronic and structural properties of the catalyst. Interestingly, Tsuchida et al.; [25] conducted a comparative study on DRM at 550 °C utilizing supported low-loading (0.05 wt. %) metal catalysts (M = Rh, Ru, Pt, Pd, Ir, Au, and Ni). The results revealed that 0.05 wt. % Rh/Al₂O₃ demonstrated superior catalytic performance among the tested formulations. Systematic evaluation of various catalyst supports indicated that Al₂O₃ provides optimal functionality for Rh-based catalysts, with Rh species supported on Al₂O₃ exhibiting significantly enhanced activity compared to those supported on SiO₂. Mechanistic studies comparing the catalytic behavior of Rh nanoparticles versus single-atom Rh suggested that nanoparticulate morphology potentially offers superior performance in DRM reactions. Furthermore, the investigation revealed that carbonaceous deposits formed on 0.05 wt. % Rh/Al₂O₃ undergo continuous removal via CO₂-mediated gasification, thereby maintaining catalytic stability during prolonged operation. Recently, Sm₂O₃/Co, Sm₂O₃/Ni, Al₂O₃/Co, Al₂O₃/Ni, and Al₂O₃/Co-Ni are among the catalysts that Cihlar et al.; [27] synthesized and characterized for DMR. High methane conversion efficiencies (93–98 %) and varied carbon deposition rates (0.01–4.35 mg C/gcat·h) were shown by catalytic assessment. Maximum carbonaceous deposition was observed on Al₂O₃/Co and Al₂O₃/Ni formulations, attributed to the formation of metal-aluminum alloys. Kinetic analysis revealed that the rate of methane cracking exceeded that of CO₂ reduction, leading to enhanced carbon formation. Notably, samarium-containing catalysts (Sm-Co-O and Sm-Ni-O) exhibited significantly reduced carbon deposition, analogous to lanthanum-based systems. This superior carbon resistance was attributed to the inherent basicity of Sm₂O₃ and enhanced oxygen mobility at the active sites, which facilitated the gasification of carbon deposits. Herein, we present the first comprehensive evaluation of a specific set of 1 % (Rh, La, Au, and Sm) promoters in 5 % Ni/Al2O3 catalysts for DRM at 700 °C. Comprehensive characterization techniques, including N₂ physisorption, H₂-TPR, XRD, CO₂-TPD, Raman spectroscopy, TEM, and XPS, were employed to analyze the catalyst properties. The results revealed that Rh promotion enhanced Ni reducibility and improved nickel nanoparticle dispersion, whereas La, Au, and Sm promoted unexpectedly increased carbon deposition, as confirmed by Raman spectroscopy. Statistical analysis using response surface methodology identified the reaction temperature as the most critical parameter, significantly enhancing CO and H₂ production. The H₂/CO ratio was found to increase with higher temperatures and lower space velocities, as well as with simultaneous increases in both temperature and CH₄/CO₂ ratio. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 98 %), alumina (Al2O3, 99.95 %), rhodium nitrate (Rh (NO3)2, 98 %), lanthanum nitrate (La(NO3)2, 99.9 %), gold nitrate (Au(NO3)2, 99.99 %) and samarium nitrate (Sm(NO3)2,99.9 %). All chemicals were of analytical grade and were used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The necessary amounts of active metals of 5 % Ni (NO3)2·6H2O, 1 % metal (x) nitrate, and Al2O3 as support were impregnated to create a series of aqueous solutions consisting of 5 % Ni-1 %x/94 % (Al2O3), where x = Rh, La, Au, and Sm. A certain volume of distilled water was used to dissolve and fully combine nickel nitrate hexahydrate. To create a homogeneous solution, Rh, La, Au, and Sm nitrate solutions were added separately. A slurry was created by heating the mixture to 80 °C while stirring. The sample was dried at 120 °C for 16 h and then calcined at 600 °C for 3 h to remove any residual water. For comparison, an aqueous solution of 5 % Ni (NO3)2·6H2O and Al2O3 was directly synthesized using the same procedure. The produced catalysts were then milled into powders. 5Ni/Al2O3, 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3, 5Ni-La/Al2O3, 5Ni-Au/Al2O3, and 5Ni-Sm/Al2O3 were the donated forms of the prepared catalysts. 2.3 Assessment of catalyst performance A stainless-steel packed bed reactor was used to assess the catalytic performance for DRM at 700 °C and atmospheric pressure. Within the reactor, a 0.1 g catalyst sample was placed on glass wool. Temperature monitoring during the reaction was facilitated by a K-type thermocouple sheathed in stainless steel and axially positioned in proximity to the catalyst bed. Before reaction initiation, catalyst activation was conducted at 700 °C with hydrogen for an hour, followed by nitrogen purging to eliminate residual hydrogen. The DRM reaction was performed with a feed composition of CH₄: CO₂: N₂ at a volumetric ratio of 3:3:1, and the feed flow rate was 70 mL/min. Online gas chromatography with a PropakQ column, molecular sieve columns, and a thermal conductivity detector was used to analyze the effluent gas. The following Eqs. (5–7) were used to quantify the H2 and CO yields and H2/CO ratios. The creation of new catalysts and triplicate testing from the start were used to evaluate experimental reproducibility and repeatability to guarantee methodological rigor. (5) H 2 Yield ( % ) = Mol of H 2 , out 2 * C H 4 ( converted ) x 100 (6) CO Yield ( % ) = mol of C O out mol of C H 4 , in + mol of C O 2 , in × 100 (7) H 2 CO = mole of H 2 produced mole of CO produced 2.4 Catalyst characterization A Micromeritics Tristar II 3020 instrument was used to characterize the textural characteristics of the catalyst samples, including surface area, pore volume, pore diameter, and N₂ adsorption-desorption isotherms (Micromeritics, USA). Surface area calculations were performed using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller equation, while the pore size distribution was determined through nonlocal density functional theory modeling. X-ray diffraction analysis was conducted using a Bruker Apex II Diffractometer, with powder samples sealed in capillaries (0.3–1 mm diameter). Data acquisition was feasible within a temperature range of 80–320 K. Raman spectroscopic analysis was performed utilizing a laser Raman spectrometer operating at 532 nm excitation wavelength with 1.6 mW laser power. Samples were subjected to three accumulations with a 10-second exposure duration. The redox properties and surface chemistry of the catalysts were investigated via H₂-temperature-programmed reduction (H₂-TPR) and CO₂-temperature-programmed desorption (CO₂-TPD) using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For the H₂-TPR analysis, 70 mg of catalyst was heated to 900 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min under 10 % H₂/He flow (40 mL/min), with water vapor removed via a cold trap. TCD measurements recorded the conductivity variations corresponding to gas desorption or H₂ consumption. The XPS stands for X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Using a flood cannon for charge adjustment, the Thermo K Alpha spectrometer uses Al K alpha X-rays (1486.6 eV) with a 400 μm spot size. Additionally, as an internal standard, all binding energy estimates were standardized to C1s = 284.6 eV. A JEOL JEM-1400 transmission electron microscope operating at 120 kV accelerating voltage was used to perform transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurements of the fresh and spent samples in order to thoroughly examine the morphology of the deposited carbon. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Results and discussion of characterization Fig. 1 presents the nitrogen physisorption isotherms of the synthesized catalysts, exhibiting characteristics consistent with IUPAC Type IV classification. Before the inflection point, the isotherms show a characteristic final saturation plateau that starts at a relative pressure (P/P₀) of roughly 0.9. The physisorption properties of the catalyst specimens were insignificant and were minimally affected by the addition of Rh, La, Au, and Sm dopants. The mesoporous character of the produced catalysts was confirmed by the observed hysteresis loops, which are suggestive of capillary condensation processes in which the gaseous adsorbate changes into a quasi-liquid phase inside the pore structure at sub-saturation pressures in comparison to the bulk liquid. This phenomenon occurs when the pore dimensions exceed a critical threshold, which is temperature-dependent [28]. The hysteresis loops in this study include hybrid H2(b)/H5 properties, which are commonly connected to pore-blocking mechanisms according to the IUPAC nomenclature [29]. This morphological feature is anticipated due to structural modifications induced by nickel impregnation and/or the incorporation of various metallic components in the catalyst formulation. One of the most important markers of the catalytic oxidation characteristics of metal oxide supports is the hydrogen reduction temperature. Fig. 2 illustrates how different metals (Rh, La, Au, and Sm) affect the catalysts' hydrogen reduction temperature profiles. A large reduction peak between 530 °C and 675 °C was observed for the 5Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, which is indicative of the moderate interaction between Ni and the support. The most intense reduction peak at approximately 900 °C over 5Ni/Al2O3 indicates the strong interaction of NiO with the alumina support or may be a reduction of nickel aluminum oxide [30]. The inverted peaks around 230 °C indicate strong metal-support interactions, which may lead to complex reduction behavior [22]. At temperatures above 500 °C, the 5Ni/Al2O3 catalyst and those containing La and Sm exhibited unique profiles, with reduction peaks discernible at approximately 675 °C and 900 °C. At the expense of the reduction peak intensity at 900 °C, the strength of the reduction peak at approximately 675 °C increased. This indicates that upon the addition of La and Sm, the strong interaction of NiO partially turns to a moderate interaction. Interestingly, the high-temperature peak at approximately 900 °C shifted to 800 °C upon the addition of Au over 5Ni/Al2O3. In contrast, the 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3 catalyst showed bimodal profiles at lower temperatures (around 450 °C and 750 °C), with an enhanced reduction peak intensity at 450 °C. These observations indicate the higher edge of reduction upon promotional addition of Au or Rh over 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3. In conclusion, the shifts and intensities of the peaks show that while the promoters do not vary the number of reduction steps, they do modify how easy or difficult these steps are. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted on the 5Ni/Al2O3 and promoted 5Ni-Sm/Al2O3, 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3, 5Ni-La/Al2O3, and 5Ni-Au/Al2O3 catalysts to elucidate their crystallographic structures, as illustrated in Fig. 3 . As evidenced by the diffraction patterns, all samples exhibited characteristic diffraction peaks of Al₂O₃ support at (2θ = 45.8°, 66.2°) and spinel NiAl₂O₄ at (2θ = 37.9°, 45.6°, 64.8°), showing that throughout the catalysts' calcination process, spinel NiAl₂O₄ formed, resulting in contacts between the active nickel species and the support material [24,31–33]. Significantly, the promoted catalysts exhibited negligible structural deviations compared to the unpromoted sample, indicating homogeneous and efficient dispersion of Sm, Rh, La, and Au species across the 5Ni/Al2O3 catalyst surface. The absence of distinct metal phases for the promoters may be attributed to the loaded quantities of Sm, Rh, La, and Au being below the detection threshold of the XRD technique, a phenomenon consistent with observations reported in previous investigations [23,24]. The basicity characteristics of 5Ni/Al2O3 and the promoted catalysts were quantitatively assessed via CO2-Temperature Programmed Desorption (CO2-TPD) analysis, as illustrated in Fig. 4 . With two separate desorption maxima at about 100 °C and 300 °C, which correspond to weak and moderate basic sites, respectively, the data show that the 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3 catalyst has a low capacity for CO2 adsorption. Comparative analysis of other promoted catalysts with the 5Ni/Al2O3 revealed analogous desorption profiles at identical temperature ranges; however, the low temperature peaks manifested increased intensities of the promoted samples. Interestingly, the catalyst samples show the presence of strong basic sites with weak intensity between 600 °C and 850 °C, which gives rise to stable carbonates peaks [22]. The strong basic sites in these samples may present challenges to their catalytic activity. The high basicity levels cause CO₂ dissociation but create a risk of catalyst deactivation and thus pose negative effects on the system. The catalyst surface activity suffers an additional decline through the Boudouard reaction at higher temperatures because it leads to carbon deposition as coke, along with carbon monoxide dissociation. 3.2 Results and discussion of catalytic activity Fig. 5 A illustrates the temporal hydrogen yield progression during DRM at 700 °C compared with the various promoted catalysts against the 5Ni/Al2O3 reference. This section examines the catalytic performance modifications induced by incorporating Rh, La, Au, and Sm into the 5Ni/Al2O3 system. The data demonstrate that the 5Ni-Au/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits lower initial hydrogen productivity than both 5Ni/Al2O3 and other promoted catalysts. A discernible performance hierarchy emerges among the tested catalysts, arranged in ascending order of efficacy: 5Ni-Au/Al2O3 < 5Ni-Sm/Al2O3 = 5Ni-La/Al2O3 < 5Ni/Al2O3 < 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3. The hydrogen yield of the 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3 catalyst was approximately 60 %. The synergistic interaction between the Rh and Ni species, which enables a higher edge of reducibility than that of the other catalysts, is responsible for the improved performance. The synergistic effect between Rh and Ni can be attributed to the Rh, being more electronegative than Ni, creates electron-deficient Ni sites that enhance CO₂ activation while maintaining optimal CH₄ dissociation kinetics. This will be supported by the XPS binding energy shifts. In addition, Rh atoms likely occupy specific coordination environments that optimize the ensemble size for CH bond activation while preventing excessive carbon deposition, as evidenced by TEM particle size analysis. Here, the catalysts underwent reductive treatment at 700 °C. The 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3 catalyst has more active sites than the other catalysts up to 700 °C because of its greater reducibility. In rest catalysts (5Ni/Al2O3 and 4Ni-M/Al2O3; M = Au, La, Sm), the majority of the active sites surged beyond 700 °C and were not accessible for the DRM reaction. Catalytic performance is severely hampered by the presence of La, Sm, and Au in a variety of ways. Unfortunately, CH₄ breakdown is preferred over CO₂ activation due to the formation of La₂O₃ patches, which physically block active Ni sites and enhance surface basicity. Sm produces acid-base pairs that encourage polymerization reactions that result in coke precursors, as well as Sm₂O₃ islands that interact poorly with Ni. Au reduces the active surface area by forming big metallic particles with poor dispersion, and its weak CO₂ activation capability causes the reaction stoichiometry to shift towards carbon production. While Al₂O₃ is a common support, the interaction of different promoters with its surface chemistry (acid/base balance) can significantly influence Ni anchoring and metal-support interaction, thus altering performance. Analogous trends were observed for the CO yield as a function of time, as depicted in Fig. 5 B, during DRM conducted at 700 °C. The higher CO-yield than the H2-yield over all catalysts indicates the substantial presence of hydrogen-consuming reactions (such as the reverse water-gas shift reaction) along with the DRM reaction. The incorporation of noble metal and rare-earth elements (Rh, La, Au, and Sm) into 5Ni/Al2O3 promoted in distinct catalytic responses. Experimental data indicated that the 5Ni-Au/Al2O3 formulation demonstrated diminished initial CO production efficiency compared to both 5Ni/Al2O3 and other promoted catalysts. The quantitative evaluation revealed a distinct activity sequence among the catalysts under investigation, which might be arranged in ascending order of catalytic efficacy: 5Ni-Au/Al2O3 < 5Ni-La/Al2O3 < 5Ni-Sm/Al2O3 < 5Ni/Al2O3 < 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3. The 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited outstanding performance, achieving H2 and CO yields of approximately 60 % and 70 %, respectively. Fig. 5 C presents the temporal evolution of the H₂/CO ratio during DRM at 700 °C, providing a comparative analysis of the various promoted catalysts relative to the unpromoted 5Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. This investigation examines the modifications in the catalytic behavior resulting from the incorporation of noble metals (Rh, Au) and rare earth elements (La, Sm) into the 5Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. The experimental data reveal that all synthesized catalysts exhibit comparable H₂/CO ratios, confined within a narrow range of 0.81–0.9. Notably, the 5Ni-La/Al2O3, 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3, and 5Ni-Au/Al2O3 formulations demonstrated marginally superior performance, with H₂/CO ratios approaching 0.85 than the non-promoted catalyst. Interestingly, the H2 ratios over the 5Ni-Sm/Al2O3 and 5Ni-La/Al2O3 catalysts are quite comparable, but the CO yield over the 5Ni-Sm/Al2O3 catalyst is significantly higher than that of the 5Ni-La/Al2O3 catalyst. This means that during the DRM reaction, 5Ni-Sm/Al2O3 generates more CO than 5Ni-La/Al2O3, whereas the hydrogen production capacities of the two catalysts are comparable. This resulted in a decrease in the H2/CO ratio to a minimum value over the Sm-promoted 5Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. Figure S1 illustrates the effect of temperature on the yields of CO and H₂ using a Ni+1Rh/Al₂O₃ catalyst under specific operating conditions, with temperatures ranging from 700 °C to 850 °C. Both CO and H₂ yields increase significantly with rising temperature. Throughout the studied range, the CO yield remains consistently higher than that of H₂. However, the gap between CO and H₂ yields narrows as the temperature approaches 850 °C, indicating that the two product lines are converging. This trend suggests that the reaction is approaching equilibrium or its maximum conversion efficiency at higher temperatures. A comparative analysis of various catalytic systems is provided in Table 1 . Our catalyst (Rh/Ni/Al₂O₃) achieved a 70 % CO yield and 60 % H₂ yield, with an H₂/CO ratio of 0.85 at 700 °C. These results are systematically compared with those reported by El Hassan et al., [34] in which a Rh-Ni/SiO₂ catalyst achieved 64 % CH₄ conversion at 500 °C. This comparison highlights the superior performance of our Al₂O₃-supported system at elevated temperatures. Additionally, the H₂/CO ratio of 0.85 is well-suited for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis, falling within the optimal range (0.6–0.9) commonly reported in the literature [12,27,28]. Raman spectroscopic analysis was utilized to investigate the structural characteristics and physicochemical properties of carbonaceous deposits formed on catalyst surfaces during the DRM. Fig. 6 presents the Raman spectral profiles of all catalysts following a 7-hour aging process under DRM conditions at 700 °C. The presence of the D, G, and 2D bands in all spectra confirms the formation of coke on the surface of all catalysts after the reaction. The spectral data revealed two characteristic peaks at approximately 1352 cm⁻¹ and 1583 cm⁻¹, corresponding to the D and G bands, respectively. The D band arises from vibrational modes of sp² hybridized carbon atoms within disordered structures, while the G band is attributed to sp² hybridized carbon atoms within ordered carbon domains [37]. The intensity ratio of these bands (ID/IG) serves as a quantitative metric for assessing the structural disorder and defect concentration within carbonaceous material [10,26]. Comparative analysis revealed that the promoted 5Ni-Sm/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited a higher ID/IG ratio than that of the 5Ni-La/Al2O3 catalyst (1.23 vs 1.05), indicating that carbonaceous deposits on the former possess a lower degree of graphitization. This finding suggests the formation of fewer graphitic carbon structures on the 5Ni-Sm/Al2O3 catalyst following the DRM reaction. 5Ni/Al₂O₃, 5Ni-Rh/Al₂O₃, and 5Ni-Au/Al₂O₃ show intermediate ID/IG ratios (1.21, 1.19, and 1.12, respectively), suggesting intermediate levels of disorder in their carbon formations. Fig. 7 shows transmission electron micrographs (TEM) of fresh and spent 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3 catalysts calcined at 700 °C. The TEM analysis of these catalysts is presented in Fig. 7 (A-F) at multiple magnification levels. The micrographs shown in Fig. 7 (A-C) exhibit regions of light contrast, indicating areas where electrons have experienced minimal scattering or absorption. Conversely, the dark regions correspond to areas where electrons undergo stronger scattering or absorption by the 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3 catalyst nanoparticles. The TEM characterization confirms the homogeneous distribution of 5Ni-Rh nanoparticles throughout the Al2O3 catalyst matrix, visualized as dark spots. The spent 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3 samples demonstrate slightly enhanced dispersion post-process. Additionally, these spent samples reveal that a significant proportion of metallic active sites became encapsulated by carbon nanotubes or nanofibers, as evidenced in Fig. 7 D-F. This carbon deposition phenomenon resulted in catalyst deactivation during dry reforming through a coking mechanism, consistent with observations reported by Drif et al. [9]. To clarify the promotional effect of Rh, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was utilized to examine the surface chemical states of Ni in the as-prepared 5Ni/Al2O3 and 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3 catalysts. The corresponding Ni 2p spectra are shown in Fig. 8 . The binding energy (BE) values of Ni 2p₃/₂ for both fresh catalysts were analyzed. The BE value of Ni 2p₃/₂ in the 5Ni/ Al2O3 catalyst at 861.1 eV, accompanied by satellite signals at 866.7 eV, and Ni 2p1/2 signal at 879.1 eV, confirmed the presence of Ni in the form of NiAl₂O₄ [31,38,39], indicating incorporation of Ni into the Al₂O₃ lattice to form spinel oxide structures. Notably, compared to the 5Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3's Ni 2p₃/₂ peaks showed a minor change in favor of higher binding energies. This observation further supported the production of NiAl2O₄ and the enhanced metal-support interaction between the modified support and the active nickel species, both of which greatly enhanced the catalyst's stability. In conjunction with XRD results, the Ni²⁺ species were confirmed to be predominantly associated with the formation of NiAl₂O₄ throughout the catalysts' calcination process. The formation of NiAl₂O₄ spinel phase during calcination/reduction significantly impacts catalyst performance by creating irreducible Ni species. Rh acts as a beneficial promoter by disrupting the Ni-Al₂O₃ interface, which in turn prevents the undesirable diffusion of Ni²⁺ into tetrahedral Al₂O₃ sites. Additionally, Rh's donation of electron density to Ni effectively stabilizes Ni in its metallic (Ni⁰) state, making Ni⁰ thermodynamically more favorable than Ni²⁺ in the spinel structure. On the other hand, La and Sm may increase the basicity and interaction with the Al₂O₃ support, enhancing Ni incorporation into the spinel lattice and thus promoting NiAl₂O₄ formation. This is supported by the broader TPR peaks at higher temperatures, indicating harder-to-reduce Ni species. 4 Response surface methodology (RSM) The Central Composite Design (CCD) methodology was employed, where the factors are transformed into standardized, dimensionless variables ranging from −1 to +1. Space velocity, temperature, and the CH₄/CO₂ mole ratio, all of which fall within a particular range, are the experimental variables that are investigated in this work. Each range's midpoint represents the respective factor's central value, while the deviation from this midpoint quantifies the variation limits. This transformation ensures consistency in statistical modeling and response surface evaluation. The central point, defined by the mean values of all factors, serves as a critical reference for detecting curvature in the response surface. This approach allows for a more precise understanding of the relationships between the experimental factors and the response variable. In this study, a quadratic model was chosen instead of a higher-order (cubic or beyond) model because it effectively captures the key nonlinear relationships and interactions between factors while maintaining simplicity and interpretability. Higher-order models, though more flexible, would require additional experimental data to ensure reliability and could introduce unnecessary complexity, increasing the risk of overfitting without significantly improving predictive accuracy. (8) Y ^ = β 0 + ∑ i = 1 3 β i X i + ∑ i = 1 3 β ii X i 2 + ∑ i = 1 2 ∑ j = i + 1 3 β ij X i X j + ε The input components X 1 , X 2 , X 3 , which can be represented as actual or coded values, determine the response variable Y. Epsilon is used to account for unexplained variability in the regression model, which also includes coefficients for the intercept ( β 0 ), linear ( β i ), quadratic ( β i i ), and interaction term ( β i j ), [40]. ANOVA is used to assess the model's accuracy [41]. The study factors' actual and coded values are shown in Table 2 . 5 Analysis of variance and process modelling Model data fitting was enhanced, the response variance was stabilized, and its distribution was normalized. An effective power transformation for normalizing or equalizing variance in the response data was found using the Central Composite Design (CCD) method [41]. To evaluate model fitness, ANOVA and the prediction statistics in Table 3 were calculated. At the 95 % confidence level, significant models for every term in the polynomial equation are indicated by (Fig. 9 ) high F-values and low P-values. High R2 values attest to the experimental results' good model fit. At the 95 % confidence level, the response is considerably impacted by coefficients with P-values <0.05. A key criterion for assessing model validity is the calculation of the F-ratio, which compares the model's fit to experimental data. The calculated F-value is compared to the critical F-value, derived from the degrees of freedom and significance level (α = 0.05). If the calculated F-value is greater than the critical F-value, the model is considered to adequately fit the data [42–46]. 6 Final equation in terms of actual factors By applying ANOVA with a significance level of α = 0.05 and using the Stat-Ease package, we analyze the experimental data and propose the following models in Eqs. Fig. 10 illustrates how increasing the temperature, lowering the CH₄/CO₂ ratio, and decreasing the SV all improve CO production. Similarly, Fig. 11 shows that the H₂ yield increased with increasing temperature, decreasing SV, and lowering the CH₄/CO₂ ratio. Fig. 12 shows that lowering SV and raising the temperature and CH₄/CO₂ ratio improved H₂/CO. 8.2 Two factors effects and 3D plots The plots in the 3D representation of the models in Eqs. (9)– (11) were derived and are presented in Figs. 13–18 . For each factor in their original units, these plots were used to visualize the response variable at the assumed levels. Three-dimensional response surface plots are shown in Figs. 13 and 14, which demonstrate the important impacts of temperature, SV, and the CH₄/CO₂ ratio on CO production. While CH₄/CO₂ is constant at 1, Fig. 13 illustrates the relationship between CO yield and two variables (temperature and gas hourly space velocity (GHSV)). The plot shows that CO production was greatly increased by increasing the temperature and lowering the SV. Similarly, Fig. 14. presents the relationship between CO yield and temperature alongside the CH₄/CO₂ ratio, keeping SV constant at 35,000 ccg⁻¹h⁻¹. The response surface indicates that the CO yield increases as the temperature increases, and the CH₄/CO₂ ratio decreases. In both cases, the CO yield improved from 49.47 % at 700 °C to 91.68 % at 850 °C, with temperature exerting the most significant influence on this variation. Figs. 15 and 16 show the three-dimensional response surface plots that show how temperature, GHSV, and the CH₄/CO₂ ratio significantly affect the variance in H₂ yield. In Fig. 15, where CH₄/CO₂ is fixed at 1, an increase in temperature and a decrease in SV results in an increase in the H₂ yield from 43.88 % at 700 °C to 95.42 % at 850 °C. Similarly, Fig. 16 illustrates that the H₂ yield exhibits an increasing trend with SV maintained at 35,000 mL g⁻¹ h⁻¹ as the temperature rises from 700 °C to 85 °C and the CH₄/CO₂ ratio falls from 1.5 to 0.5. Lastly, 3D response surface plots showing the substantial impacts of temperature, GHSV, and CH₄/CO₂ ratio on H₂/CO are shown in Figs. 17 and 18. In Fig. 17, with CH₄/CO₂ fixed at 1, an increase in temperature and a decrease in gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) raise H₂/CO from 0.8 at 700 °C to a maximum of 1.1 at 850 °C. Similarly, Fig. 18. shows that increasing both temperature and CH₄/CO₂ at SV = 35,000 leads to a higher H₂/CO ratio, following the same range of increase. 8.3 Optimum conditions A numerical optimization analysis was conducted for the synthesis and evaluation of 1 % Rh-promoted Ni catalysts for enhanced hydrogen production in the dry reforming of methane using the response surface methodology. An optimum condition was obtained for H2 yield as shown in Table 5 . The experimental conditions closely matched the theoretical conditions, indicating that the RSM model is reliable for predicting the optimal outcomes for this catalyst and reaction. The H2 yield was very high, at over 95 % in both cases. Table 5. The optimum condition from the suggested best solution was selected and used for further experiments to validate the RSM model. The table effectively presents the results of an optimization study, showing how well the theoretical model aligns with practical experimental results for achieving high hydrogen production. The optimal H2 yield produced by the 5Ni+1 %Rh/Al₂O₃ catalyst of this work was compared to other catalysts discovered in scientific literature in Table S1, which compares the hydrogen yields for different catalysts in dry methane reforming. Both the experimental and anticipated H2 yields are shown in the table, along with the corresponding references. 9 Conclusion The study reveals that promoters have a significant impact on the catalytic performance of 5Ni/Al2O3 for methane dry reforming. Because of the greater reducibility and dispersion of active sites, Rh promotion showed a synergistic impact with Ni, resulting in increased catalytic activity. The inclusion of La, Au, and Sm, on the other hand, reduced catalytic performance, as a result of increased coke production and partial blocking of active sites. The physicochemical characteristics of the catalysts and how they relate to the observed catalytic behavior were revealed by characterization procedures. All catalysts had confirmed NiAl2O₄ spinel production, which affected the stability of the catalyst and the metal-support interaction. The results demonstrate how important promoter selection is to maximize the DRM performance of Ni-based catalysts. In the investigated reaction system, high temperatures and low space velocities are generally advantageous for optimizing both CO and H₂ yields, according to the response surface analysis. Furthermore, larger yields of both target products are encouraged by a lower CH₄/CO₂ ratio. Higher temperatures and lower space velocities are beneficial for the H₂/CO ratio, and improving the CH₄/CO₂ ratio and temperature together also improves the H₂/CO ratio. These results offer useful information for adjusting reaction conditions to produce the intended product distribution. In comparison to numerous catalysts found in the literature, the 1 % Rh-promoted Ni catalyst showed remarkable performance, producing >95 % H2 yield under optimized circumstances, confirming the RSM model and demonstrating its better efficacy. coredata.dc:description: Dry reforming methane (DRM) is a method that produces hydrogen, which is highly promotional and environmentally relevant. In addition to providing a route to cleaner energy production via hydrogen fuel, it offers a double environmental advantage by utilizing two powerful greenhouse gases at the same time: CO₂ and CH₄. The DRM at 700 °C was tested using a series of 5 % Ni-based catalysts promoted with 1 % Rh, La, Au, and Sm and supported on alumina. The catalysts were prepared via the impregnation method. The textural qualities, reducibility, structural features, basicity, carbon deposition, morphology, and surface chemical states were examined using N₂ physisorption, H₂-TPR, XRD, CO₂-TPD, Raman spectroscopy, TEM, and XPS. Rh addition significantly increased the catalytic activity, resulting in the highest H₂ and CO yields (approximately 60 % and 70 %, respectively) and an H₂/CO ratio of 0.85. However, when compared to the unpromoted 5Ni/Al₂O₃ catalyst, the addition of La, Au, and Sm resulted in a decline in catalytic performance, highlighting the selectivity of promoter effectiveness. According to characterization investigations, La, Au, and Sm promotion increased coke deposition, which was validated by Raman spectroscopy, while Rh promotion promoted higher reducibility and improved the dispersion of Ni nanoparticles. TEM investigation of the spent 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3 catalyst revealed that carbon nanotubes and nanofibers encapsulated the active sites. XPS analysis revealed the presence of NiAl₂O4 species in both fresh 5Ni/Al2O3 and 5Ni-Rh/Al2O3 catalysts. The Rh-promoted catalyst showed a modest shift towards higher binding energies, indicating improved metal-support interactions. Using response surface methods, this study examines how temperature, space velocity (SV), and the ratio of CH₄ to CO₂ affect the CO and H₂ yields and their ratios. The findings indicate that the most important component is temperature, which significantly increases the CO and H₂ output. These yields are also improved by lowering SV and the CH₄/CO₂ ratio. As a result, the H₂/CO ratio increased with higher temperature and lower SV, but it also increased with both temperature and CH₄/CO₂. In DRM, the ideal conditions for the 1 % Rh-promoted Ni catalyst were determined through numerical optimization, yielding over 95 % H2 yield. The experimental findings closely matched the theoretical expectations.
